text: A little late, but I’ll chime in with a personal experience. I recently was on the receiving end of a direct mailer package from a vendor who would like my business. They sent a book to my home address. This felt very creepy (how did they get my home address? Does their sales staff know where I live?). It would have been MUCH more well-received from me if they’d contacted me through email first and asked me to opt in to receiving a direct mailer, and asked for my preferred address where I’d like it to be sent.

elements.text: A little late, but I’ll chime in with a personal experience. I recently was on the receiving end of a direct mailer package from a vendor who would like my business. text:
*Are content marketing awards a thing? If so, any you’d recommend?* 
We’re particularly proud of a recent piece of content and wondering if there’s any respectable/legitimate awards that we should consider. We don’t necessarily need/want more eyeballs or bragging rights (although those things never hurt!). The part we’re particularly proud of: our team tried a new-to-them format, experimented, learned a lot, and chose some unconventional KPIs. So we’re mostly interested in sharing this story and encouraging others to try a similar approach.

elements.text: Are content marketing awards a thing? If so, any you’d recommend?

We’re particularly proud of a recent piece of content and wondering if there’s any respectable/legitimate awards that we should consider. We don’t necessarily need/want more eyeballs or bragging rights (although those things never hurt!). The part we’re particularly proud of: our team tried a new-to-them format, experimented, learned a lot, and chose some unconventional KPIs. So we’re mostly interested in sharing this story and encouraging others to try a similar approach.

text: Not heard of any awards, but you've definitely sparked my interest about your winning experiment! Would be super cool if you could share!

elements.text: Not heard of any awards, but you've definitely sparked my interest about your winning experiment! Would be super cool if you could share!

text: Ah, sorry if I was unclear. This wasn’t an experiment of the A/B variation (in other words, there was no “winner”). It was more of an _experimental_ project since this content format was new to our team (lots of ideate > implement > learn > repeat). We created a web comic about email deliverability and used “joy” as a marketing KPI. It was pretty successful, so we created a 2nd comic and even toyed with the idea of a video game. <https://postmarkapp.com/postmark-express|Here are the comics>.

attachments.text: Postmark Express: Enjoy our web comics about the Wild West of sending email. Yeehaw.
attachments.title: Email Comics by Postmark

text:
<@U01P13NTGG6> It's worth experimenting with.

The same text as an update on LinkedIn might get 5 likes but the image gets 500... If it works... It works... But I personally think you should at the very least remove the breadcrumbs from the original post. Especially brands.

text:
Need Help

a) What should be the ultimate goal of webinars? (We are a B2B SaaS tool in HR niche)
b) Also, anyone here has done webinars for their SaaS? How was the response? Worth spending time?

elements.text:
Need Help

a) What should be the ultimate goal of webinars? (We are a B2B SaaS tool in HR niche)
b) Also, anyone here has done webinars for their SaaS? How was the response? Worth spending time?

text:
(A) Be more valuable than having spent the time doing anything else. Most webinars spend 45 mins to deliver like 3 mins of value (i.e. I could've read the key points in a 500 word article and been done with it).

For the love of all things sacred, Shift webinars from: "here's some boring people reading slides at you" to:

• real networking opportunities
• solving a problem live, together, as a group
• lightning insight rounds, asking true experts hard questions, limiting their response time, then allowing expansion on the subject matter afterward in longform content, drip stuff, etc.

elements.text:
(A) Be more valuable than having spent the time doing anything else. Most webinars spend 45 mins to deliver like 3 mins of value (i.e. I could've read the key points in a 500 word article and been done with it).

For the love of all things sacred, Shift webinars from: "here's some boring people reading slides at you" to:
real networking opportunities
solving a problem live, together, as a group
lightning insight rounds, asking true experts hard questions, limiting their response time, then allowing expansion on the subject matter afterward in longform content, drip stuff, etc.

text: Couldn’t have said it better myself <@U01AHL8AGBB>.

elements.text: Couldn’t have said it better myself

text:
I find myself signing up for webinars but never consuming them. There is so much content out there, you've got to have a good reason to get people to watch. 

What makes you want to use webinars <@U01J3L8CJRL><@U01J3L8CJRL> I think there are better ways to spend your time and effort than webinars.

elements.text:

text: Can vouch for the Content Marketing Institute annual awards. Reasonably priced, lots of categories.

elements.text: Can vouch for the Content Marketing Institute annual awards. Reasonably priced, lots of categories.

text: We are a B2B SaaS. Agree with <@U01AHL8AGBB> on providing the value. We try not to make webinars with a person reading slides, rather creating and moderating a discussion. For example tomorrow we will be hosting a round table with discussion around embedded learning. The goal for this one will be understanding how experts see it and if there is a place for this - so basically validating the idea. We also host QnA sessions with the users sometimes and this has got a good feedback.

elements.text: We are a B2B SaaS. Agree with

on providing the value. We try not to make webinars with a person reading slides, rather creating and moderating a discussion. For example tomorrow we will be hosting a round table with discussion around embedded learning. The goal for this one will be understanding how experts see it and if there is a place for this - so basically validating the idea. We also host QnA sessions with the users sometimes and this has got a good feedback.
